newsitem.title: USA: U.S West Coast crude rises with WTI, trade thins.
newsitem.headline: U.S West Coast crude rises with WTI, trade thins.

text.p: U.S. West Coast crude oil prices rose Tuesday in line with increasing values for West Texas Intermediate (WTI) grade, traders said.
The market for local West Coast crudes was quiet Tuesday, with discounts unchanged following several sales of Alaska North Slope (ANS) crude last week and Monday, traders said.
One small refiner in the U.S Northwest still needed to buy ANS and bid $2.25 under July WTI.
On Monday, a large, Houston-based producer sold a cargo of ANS to a U.S Northwest refiner for $2.16 off July deliveries of WTI, the U.S basis for cash and futures oil markets.
The $2.16 reflected higher volumes of imports, weak refinery margins, and a glut of buyers.
Two cargoes of Alaska North Slope (ANS) crude sold Thursday and Friday, at $2.10 and $2.07 a barrel under July West Texas Intermediate (WTI).
The previous ANS deal was done at $1.75 in late May.
Outright prices for ANS were $17.04/17.24 a barrel, up 20 cents from Monday.
Heavier California grades remained unchanged near postings this week.
